And He said that He might bring us to God this morning. I would say that today is the day of salvation. But I want to make this final appeal to you this morning. As we have this time of invitation, I wonder if you'd make a commitment, not to me, but to God. That this week, that some would refer to as a holy week and all the events that took place, would you make a commitment to God this week that you'll tell somebody that He took their place? See, it's wonderful to know that He took my place, but He didn't reveal that to you so that you just keep it to yourself. Maybe this week, maybe a neighbor that you've been praying for in the month of March had that opportunity to go and talk to them and say, I just wanted to let you know that Jesus took your place. He loved you so much that He died for you. The just for the unjust. And would you this week really pray that God would give you an opportunity, make a commitment to the Lord. I'm going to tell somebody how much God loves them and how God took their place so that they might have salvation, that they could be reconciled to be brought back to God. This morning, wonderful thought that's on my mind. I shared it with a couple of preacher friends. The simple title of the song that we sing, Hallelujah, What a Savior. I really don't know what else to say when you think about all these truths other than Hallelujah, What a Savior. Let's pray together. Father, we love You. God, we thank You for loving us. We thank You for the privilege that You've given us this morning to gather together. God, we thank You for Your Word, the truth of Your Word, the power of Your Word. God, I pray that each and every one that's here that has been saved, they've been redeemed with the precious blood of Christ, that God, You would help us to rejoice in our salvation. Father, if there's one that's never been saved, I pray that this morning they would understand how much You love them and how You died for them so that they might have eternal life, be reconciled. I pray, God, that You'd help each one of us that are saved to make that commitment, not to some person, but God, to You. We'd take the truth of the gospel, we'd share it with somebody this week, to tell them how You took their place on that cruel cross. The story doesn't end there. We're so thankful for the resurrection. God, I pray that You'd use us this week, that You might be glorified. Move and work in these moments as only You can. We'll thank You for it in Christ's name we pray. Would You stand with me? Heads are bowed, eyes are closed.

segments.text: chapter number three this morning, 1 Peter chapter number three, this Sunday is often
referred to as Palm Sunday. And of course, you would recognize that with regard to the
triumphal entry of the Lord Jesus Christ. And as we look at this portion of scripture
this morning, I want to remind us of a great truth that the Bible reveals to us. As you
study the pages of scripture, you'll find a truth, a teaching, a principle that we often
use the phrase to refer to it as the substitutionary atonement. And we see this principle revealed
in the Old Testament and we find the perfect fulfillment with the Lord Jesus Christ when
He took my place, when He took your place on the cross of Calvary. This morning, as
we look at 1 Peter 3 and verse number 18, the Bible says this, for Christ also hath
once suffered for sins, the just for the unjust. You see that there? That's how it's worded,
that substitutionary atonement in the text that we're looking at this morning, the just
for the unjust. Who's the just? Well, that's the Lord Jesus Christ. Who's the unjust? All
of us. He took our place. Notice when it says that He might bring us to God, being
put to death in the flesh, but quickened by the Spirit. We find that the Bible says it
this way in 2 Corinthians 5 and verse 21, for He hath made Him, that's God the Father,
made Him, God the Son, to be sin for us who knew no sin, that we might be made the righteousness
of God in Him, the substitutionary atonement. You think about the Old Testament. You think
about the sacrifices. You think about Adam and Eve in the garden. You think about the
animal that was slain so that the coverings could be provided. See, because those fig
leaves, those aprons of fig leaves were not sufficient, and we find that there was a,
the blood was required, there was an animal that was sacrificed. You think about the offering
that takes place of Cain and Abel, and of course, one that's appropriate, one that's
inappropriate, the one that comes with the blood is the accepted offering. You think
about Abraham as he would sacrifice his son Isaac on Mount Moriah, and God provides a
sanctuary. You think about the Exodus as the children of Israel would leave the land
of Egypt in that final plague, the death of the firstborn. You think about the blood that
had to be applied. And then they were to observe the Passover annually, not only so that they
would remember what happened in Egypt and how God brought them out, but so that they
would look forward by faith to one day, Christ, our Passover. We find this morning that as
we would think about and understand the timing historically of the events that transpired
nearly 2,000 years ago now, we find that the Lord Jesus Christ on this particular Sunday
that we would see on our calendars and reference in our minds as being Palm Sunday and the
triumphal entry of the Lord Jesus Christ, you would hear the shouts of the people as
it's recorded in John's Gospel in the 12th chapter in verse number 13 when they say,
Hosanna, blessed is the King of Israel that cometh in the name of the Lord. But just a
few short days after His triumphal entry, those people that were shouting, Hosanna,
now the shouts that can be heard are, crucify Him! Crucify Him! You think about just in
a few days how things change so dramatically. But the events of the crucifixion were not
a surprise to the Lord Jesus Christ. He knew that it was for that cause, that purpose,
this hour that He came to this sin-cursed world. The incarnation, the entire purpose
of Jesus becoming flesh and God taking on the form of human nature was so that He could
die in our place, the substitutionary atonement. So you know an angel could not die for you
or for me. I can't die for you and you can't die for me to pay for my sin. It required
that God in flesh, the Lord Jesus Christ, took our place, the substitutionary atonement.
I titled the message this morning, He Took My Place. No doubt as you are familiar with
the account in the Gospels, you'll be familiar with a man's name by Barabbas. You understand
that he was a man that was a criminal, that was sentenced to death. And truly as you think
about the cross of the Lord Jesus Christ and as we have in our mind's eye the understanding
of Jesus crucified and on either side a thief. In a very real way, that cross was the cross
for Barabbas. But in a spiritual application this morning, that cross was my cross and
that cross was your cross. But God loved us so much that He took my place. It's amazing.
